snippet: President Bashar al-Assad ruled out talks with the armed opposition and ignored its demand that he step down, instead using a nearly hourlong speech to justify his crackdown.
abstract: Syrian Pres Bashar al-Assad, in first public address in six months, offers peace plan with new cabinet and constitution, but rules out talks with armed opposition and justifies his harsh crackdown; Assad sounds to many as brash and defiant as he did at start of uprising in 2010, despite fact that rebels now control large parts of country; many ordinary Syrians also demand change and even longtime allies like Russia have come to believe he cannot defeat insurgency.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Hania Mourtada from Beirut; an employee of The New York Times from Damascus, Syria; Eric Schmitt from Washington; and Ellen Barry from Moscow.

lead_paragraph: President Bashar al-Assad ruled out talks with the armed opposition and ignored its demand that he step down, instead using a nearly hourlong speech to justify his crackdown.
